turns.content:
Sure, here’s an updated table with more comprehensive examples for each criterion:


| Criteria | Description | Examples | Options and Scale |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Coaching Method | The approach used by the coach to guide the client’s learning and development. This could include formal methods such as structured programs and assessments, or informal methods such as open-ended discussions and self-reflection exercises. | Formal (e.g., goal-setting, action planning) or Informal (e.g., open-ended conversations, self-reflection exercises) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coaching Style | The overall approach and demeanor of the coach towards the client. This could include empathetic and supportive styles that focus on building trust and rapport, or analytical and goal-oriented styles that focus on achieving specific outcomes. | Analytical (e.g., structured, goal-oriented) or Empathetic (e.g., supportive, nurturing) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coach Experience | The level of experience and expertise of the coach in the client’s specific field or industry. This could include the number of years of experience, the type of organizations or clients served, and the coach’s educational and professional background. | 1-3 years (e.g., newer coach, less industry-specific experience) or 4-6 years (e.g., more experienced coach, some industry-specific experience) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coach Personality | The personal qualities and characteristics of the coach that align with the client’s values and preferences. This could include factors such as communication style, leadership skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural awareness. | Creative (e.g., outside-the-box thinking, risk-taking) or Practical (e.g., methodical, focused on tangible outcomes) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Availability | The coach’s availability to meet with the client based on their schedule and preferred meeting format (e.g., in-person, virtual, phone). This could include factors such as time zone, flexibility, and responsiveness. | Morning (e.g., before 12pm), Afternoon (e.g., 12pm-6pm), or Evening (e.g., after 6pm) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Goals and Objectives | The specific goals and objectives of the client for the coaching relationship. This could include factors such as skill development, career advancement, personal growth, and work-life balance. | Leadership development (e.g., communication skills, management skills) or Work-life balance (e.g., stress management, time management) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Communication Preferences | The communication preferences of the client, such as the frequency and format of meetings, the level of formality, and the mode of communication (e.g., email, phone, video conferencing). | Weekly meetings (e.g., set time and date each week) or Bi-weekly meetings (e.g., every other week) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Feedback and Evaluation | The coach’s approach to feedback and evaluation, and the tools and methods used to measure progress and success. This could include factors such as self-assessments, 360-degree feedback, and progress reports. | Self-assessment (e.g., self-reflection, self-evaluation) or 360-degree feedback (e.g., feedback from peers, supervisors, and clients) | Scale of 1-5 |
By providing more comprehensive examples for each criterion, coaching practices can ensure that clients and coaches have a clear understanding of what each criterion entails and can make more informed decisions during the matching process. Additionally, the use of a scale can help to standardize the intake form and make it easier to compare and prioritize coaches based on their fit with the client’s preferences and needs.

Sure, here are some additional options for the examples for each criterion:


| Criteria | Description | Examples | Options and Scale |
| --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Coaching Method | The approach used by the coach to guide the client’s learning and development. This could include formal methods such as structured programs and assessments, or informal methods such as open-ended discussions and self-reflection exercises. | Formal (e.g., goal-setting, action planning, assessments, structured exercises) or Informal (e.g., open-ended conversations, self-reflection exercises, creative exercises, mindfulness practices) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coaching Style | The overall approach and demeanor of the coach towards the client. This could include empathetic and supportive styles that focus on building trust and rapport, or analytical and goal-oriented styles that focus on achieving specific outcomes. | Analytical (e.g., structured, goal-oriented, results-focused, accountability-driven) or Empathetic (e.g., supportive, nurturing, compassionate, holistic) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coach Experience | The level of experience and expertise of the coach in the client’s specific field or industry. This could include the number of years of experience, the type of organizations or clients served, and the coach’s educational and professional background. | 1-3 years (e.g., newer coach, less industry-specific experience, general coaching expertise) or 4-6 years (e.g., more experienced coach, some industry-specific experience, specialized coaching expertise) or 7+ years (e.g., highly experienced coach, extensive industry-specific experience, recognized coaching expertise) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Coach Personality | The personal qualities and characteristics of the coach that align with the client’s values and preferences. This could include factors such as communication style, leadership skills, emotional intelligence, and cultural awareness. | Creative (e.g., outside-the-box thinking, risk-taking, innovative, adaptable) or Practical (e.g., methodical, focused on tangible outcomes, strategic, results-oriented) or Personable (e.g., friendly, approachable, easy to talk to, empathetic) or Professional (e.g., formal, direct, confident, authoritative) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Availability | The coach’s availability to meet with the client based on their schedule and preferred meeting format (e.g., in-person, virtual, phone). This could include factors such as time zone, flexibility, and responsiveness. | Morning (e.g., before 9am), Mid-day (e.g., 9am-5pm), or Evening (e.g., after 5pm) or Virtual (e.g., video conferencing, phone) or In-person (e.g., face-to-face meetings) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Goals and Objectives | The specific goals and objectives of the client for the coaching relationship. This could include factors such as skill development, career advancement, personal growth, and work-life balance. | Skill Development (e.g., public speaking, time management, decision-making, problem-solving) or Career Advancement (e.g., leadership development, career transition, promotion, job search) or Personal Growth (e.g., self-awareness, confidence, resilience, well-being) or Work-Life Balance (e.g., stress management, time management, prioritization, boundaries) | Scale of 1-5 |
| Communication Preferences | The communication preferences of the client, such as the frequency and format of meetings, the level of formality, and the mode of communication (e.g., email, phone, video conferencing). | Weekly meetings (e.g., set time and date each week), Bi-weekly meetings (e.g., every other week), or Monthly meetings (e.g., |  |
more criteria and create questions for each

Sure, here are some additional criteria and questions that can be included in the intake form for matching coaches and clients:


| Criteria | Description | Example Question |
| --- | --- | --- |
| Learning Style | The client’s preferred way of learning and processing information. This could include visual, auditory, or kinesthetic learning styles. | How do you prefer to learn and process information? |
| Interests and Hobbies | The client’s interests and hobbies outside of work. This could help to identify shared interests and potential areas for personal growth. | What are some of your interests and hobbies outside of work? |
| Motivations | The client’s underlying motivations for seeking coaching, such as career advancement, personal growth, or work-life balance. | What motivated you to seek coaching at this time? |
| Feedback and Support | The client’s preferences for feedback and support, such as the frequency and format of feedback, and the level of support needed. | How often do you like to receive feedback and in what format? |
| Values and Beliefs | The client’s core values and beliefs that shape their worldview and decision-making. | What are some of your core values and beliefs that guide your life and work? |
| Cultural Awareness | The client’s cultural background and awareness, and their preferences for coaching with a coach who shares or understands their culture. | How important is it for you to work with a coach who shares or understands your cultural background? |
| Personality Traits | The client’s personality traits and characteristics that may impact their coaching relationship, such as introversion or extroversion, or openness to new experiences. | What are some of your personality traits and characteristics that you think may impact your coaching relationship? |
| Emotional Intelligence | The client’s emotional intelligence and ability to recognize and manage their own emotions and those of others. | How do you typically manage your emotions in difficult situations? |
By including these additional criteria and questions in the intake form, coaching practices can gather more comprehensive information about the client and their preferences, needs, and motivations for coaching. This can help to ensure that the matching process is more personalized and that the client is paired with a coach who is a good fit based on a range of factors. Additionally, this information can be used by coaches to tailor their coaching approach and strategies to better meet the needs of the client.
